ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Zoom seminar and Zoom office hours
discussion board on canvas, breakout rooms

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to analyze novels and write strong papers comparing different novels from the same time period.
I learned a lot about Victorian England and about some of the foremost writers of the time.
We learned a lot about the bildungsroman genre in Victorian literature. I also became a stronger writer through drafting and workshopping essays.
We had wonderful and fruitful class discussions in this course.
Knowledge of education, liberalism, feminism, and art during the Victorian time period; literary criticism; Victorian texts; becoming a more organized and developed writer.

- How to write and structure a cohesive argument
- The tenants of bildungsromane

I learned more about various Victorian novels
I learned more about writing more concise papers with a good thesis and good argument
I learned about how to think about "growing up"

This course is a great introduction to Victorian Literature and is delivered in a format that is easy and fun to access! For each novel we read, we talked about not only the themes, plot, character development etc of the writing itself, but also about the authors, process of publishing and historical implications of each text.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: such an amazing course that I absolutely love. I loved that it was a small seminar and that I could interact and have discussions with my peers. I got to know them and we would build on what we were each saying. Also, the selection of books was amazing and I could tell Professor Markovits but a lot of time thinking about the precise order to read the books in. Honestly, it make for a delightful experience comparing each novel to the one before and uncovering the ways in which the novels speak to each other through being bildungsromon novels.

I really enjoyed this course. I thought Professor Markovits was very good at leading our seminar discussions, especially considering that all of the class took place on zoom. The readings were interesting, too. I appreciated that we were able to read texts both from England itself and from the colonies. Honestly, I don't really have any complaints.

Professor Markovits is wonderful! She is incredibly smart and really cares about her students. There are many opportunities for students to receive feedback. This course is well-organized and the expectations are clear. There is a lot of reading in this course, but the novels are enjoyable. If you are interested in thinking about how growing up is shown in literature, definitely take this course!!
There was a lot of reading piled towards the beginning and not as much at the end. It could have been spread out a bit more! Otherwise, it was a great class and we read a good combination of books.

There is a LOT of reading assigned, and especially the last book we read felt pointless, as we already had to have a prospectus for the final paper submitted before we started it. I also felt like Markovits was a hard grader. I enjoyed reading the primary texts much more than the critical essays, but you can't get around those in an English class. Also, we had to have a draft of our final paper submitted on the Monday after Thanksgiving break, which caused some pain (and bewildered questioning from parents) during what was supposed to be break. That said, the discussion was always illuminating, the primary texts were mostly fantastic, and Markovits is one of the most engaging and thoughtful professors I've had during Zoom-college yet.

Strengths: Great books for the most part, fantastic professor who was a great discussion leader and also wonderful to talk to. Good amount of assignments, flexibility in topic choices for assignments
Weaknesses: Not too much interaction with peers, but that probably was influenced but the Zoom format, too.

This course was by far the best virtual discussion that I experienced this semester. The use of breakout rooms and the small class size really allowed all of the students to engage with the works together. The use of the discussion board and the requirement to post before class always meant that we had a jumping off point at the beginning of the conversation and were able to recognize our classmates for their contributions. While there is a lot of reading, all of the texts were really great and I think the sheer breadth of reading was a strength when it came time to write essays.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I honestly loved the small nature of the class. I believe that this itself was a nice thing to have during COVID, where I was away from my friends and campus. It allowed me to have a class where I could interact with other students.
Office hours were very accessible!
I thought this was one of the more successful seminars I've taken virtually, and am not really sure how I would have improved the virtual aspect of it.

I thought the virtual seminar worked pretty wellit was engaging, so I never got bored and usually time passed swiftly by. I do think it was harder for some to speak up than others, so maybe some sort of google form or something where people could put additional thoughts (if they felt shy or something) would be helpful. The canvas discussion posts are sort of like that, but not really as fun.
The small class size to keep the Zoom boxes visible was really great for engagement.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YES YES YES! I loved this course, just absolutely loved it. Not only are the book selections amazing but Professor Markovits has a way of pushing you to think about the novels in ways you never thought to before. The seminar is great because you get to actively discuss the novels and what your perspective is. It is truly amazing how two people can read the same book and get largely different takes on it. So, for this reason, I learned just as much from the Professor as I did from my peers. Also, another reason I loved this course is that it is so welcoming to non-english/literature majors. This was one of my first literature classes and I never felt out of place! Professor Markovits is extremely welcoming and fosters a great environment for you to talk about your ideas about a book or a passage, even if they are not fully fleshed out yet or you are just thinking on the spot. I can honestly say this is one of my favorite classes at Yale and I feel that students should really consider taking it. In my opinion, for non-english/literature majors, it allows you to get that well-rounded liberal arts education that Yale offers.

Yes. To be honest, I hadn't had that much experience with Victorian literature before taking this class, and I wasn't sure it would be for me. But I found both the readings and the discussions to be very rewarding! Now, I find myself really wanting to explore more texts from this era.
Yes!! This course is a Yale gem.
I would!

Just beware that there is a lot of reading that you have to stay on top of. Additionally, I found out I don't enjoy reading critical essays that much in this course, so if you feel the same way I might recommend a class with more focus on the primary texts and close-reading rather secondary essays.
Yes! I loved this course, and Professor Markovits made each seminar engaging and intellectually fulfilling! I learned so much!

Yes!!!! Wonderful books to read, and your writing will improve a lot if you take advantage of Prof. Markovits's offer to read drafts in advanceshe gives really thorough comments that make you a better writer and thinker.

Absolutely, especially for an English major. This was the best course I have taken at Yale so far and really engaged with the type of literature I am most passionate about. You get to knock some classic books off your to-read list and the two required essays have the potential to be really fun if you meet with your professor and pay attention to discussion.
